Buffalo Discovery Fund (BUFTX) turns to market disrupters like Align Technology (ALGN) and long-term secular trends in shaping its investment strategy, which has landed the fund among the top mutual funds in the third annual IBD Best Mutual Funds Awards.The $1.9 billion fund has been led by Clay Brethour, Dave Carlsen and Elizabeth Jones since 2004. "We seek the early identification of attractively priced, financially strong, well-managed companies," Carlsen said. "We take a patient approach to stock selection, looking for stock opportunities where long-term growth is underappreciated or where there's been an overreaction in the near term."The approach has paid off for the top-performing mutual fund. It has beaten the S&P 500 in each of the past one, three, five and 10 years. In doing so it won IBD Best Mutual Funds Awards in both the Growth Fund and Midcap Fund categories.Over the last 10- and 15-year periods the fund has turned in average annual returns of 13.6% and 14.7%. These gains have handily surpassed those of midcap growth funds tracked by Morningstar, which have posted 9.6% and 11.4% returns for the same periods. Where does that put it among top mutual funds? Buffalo Discovery's 10- and 15-year annual average returns ranked among the top 3% and 2% of Morningstar midcap growth funds.In 2017, Buffalo Discovery returned 25.4%. It earned a top-three ranking in the IBD Best Mutual Funds 2018 Awards list for midcap funds.Innovation is essential for inclusion in the Buffalo Discovery portfolio. "We've found that our focus on innovation is one of the best ways to hitch our wagon to share gainers and market disrupters," Carlsen said. "We believe these companies will be the most likely to reap the rewards of the big secular growth trends."Carlsen's team uses secular trends to home in on worthy portfolio candidates. "The secular trends provide a growth tailwind and narrow our stock picking universe to a durable growth universe that we believe should grow faster and have less cyclicality than the overall market," he said. "Our growth universe establishes our hunting grounds, not the constituents of a benchmark index. This purposely distances us from relative benchmark portfolio management styles leading to high active share."Get these newsletters delivered to your inbox & more info about our products & services. Privacy Policy & Terms of UseThe Buffalo Discovery team looks for companies that can gain market share in almost any market environment. "We let our innovators run," Carlsen said. "We have a preference for small- and midcap stocks with long runways for growth where the benefits of innovation are sustainable and early relative to the potential opportunity, resulting in high rates of growth for many years."Buffalo Discovery owned 86 stock holdings and maintained an annual turnover ratio of 53% as of Dec. 31. Technology, industrials and health care were its three largest sector weightings.Top holding Align Technology has been a mainstay in the portfolio for much of Carlsen's tenure. The stock has surged more than 4,000% since the maker of Invisalign was added to the portfolio in 2005, and has climbed into large-cap territory. The Buffalo Discovery team still sees plenty of room to run. "We believe robust growth is sustainable over the intermediate to long term," Carlsen said. "Less than 15% of the orthodontic market has converted from metal braces to clear aligners. The company has also been focused on driving down the cost of its product resulting in tremendous growth internationally."In Q4, Invisalign case shipments spiked 34% on a year-over-year basis.Carlsen sees the fund's stake in Nevro (NVRO) benefiting from an aging population and a government push away from opioids for pain management. "The company makes high-frequency spinal cord stimulation (SCS) devices that treat chronic back and leg pain more effectively and with better clinical outcomes than competing SCS devices from traditional players," he said. "It has rapidly gained nearly 15% market share and remains well positioned for further share gains and rapid growth. Continued product innovation like smaller footprint devices should expand the market and recent full-body MRI approval in Europe bodes well for future U.S. approval."Xylem (XYL), the No. 2 holding of the fund, enables municipal and industrial customers to manage water systems more efficiently. "They've incorporated sensors and analytics to proactively provide alerts when a problem requires attention, before it breaks and causes costly downtime," Carlsen said. "They have also incorporated intelligence on pumps to use less energy and boost efficiency. The company should have earnings growth in the midteens over the next several years."Shares of Xylem are up 50% from a year ago.In the tech space, the Buffalo Discovery team is bullish on the video game publisher Electronic Arts (EA). "Video game companies have enjoyed a strong year as investors realize the positive business model effects of downloadable games and in-game content," Carlsen said. "Emerging online player networks should help further expand the user base as players connect from around the world."Electronic Arts has seen its stock price rise 43% over the past year.Buffalo Discovery bought shares of Praxair (PX) in 2015. The industrial gas supplier was a top 10 holding at year-end. "It is a premier operator and serves a consumable (product) to a diverse set of industrial customers," Carlsen said. "This tends to insulate it from negative flash points in the economy. Its strategy is to grow profitably regardless of the macroeconomic environment. The name brings some nice stability to our portfolio."Shares of Praxair are up 31% versus a year ago.With an eye on its current holdings, the Buffalo Discovery team remains on the lookout for opportunities to add innovators to the portfolio."We believe the market frequently overreacts to near-term events, which will create opportunities to buy premier stocks at attractive prices," Carlsen said."The market volatility experienced this past February is the most recent example. Only through active management can an investor benefit from these temporary market dislocations. Anyone can ride an index fund or ETF up during the bull market, but you need the skill of an active manager to protect your capital when the tide turns."YOU MAY ALSO BE INTERESTED IN:Read The Full IBD Best Mutual Funds Awards 2018 Special ReportHere's The List Of The Best Mutual Funds Award Winners By CategoryBest Mutual Funds: News, Performance Reports And Investing IdeasHow To Invest Like Fidelity Stock Gurus Will Danoff And John RothWhich Stocks Are The Best Mutual Funds Buying — And Selling?

In an industry clogged with look-alike mutual funds, an ESG focus helps Calvert Equity Fund (CSIEX) stand out. The $2.2 billion fund bases its buy decisions not only on fundamental financial analysis but also on socially responsible criteria.X ESG refers to environmental, social and corporate governance criteria. "Investors are attracted to this approach (using ESG factors) because they want to invest in companies that are solving these pressing ESG challenges," said Anthony Eames, director of responsible investment strategy for Calvert Research & Management. "Over time, companies that get ESG factors right benefit from that, and that's good for the companies and their shareholders."The financial fundamentals that the fund's four managers screen for are designed to find "companies with consistent growth and stability in earnings," said Joseph Hudepohl, one of four Atlanta Capital Management co-managers who subadvise the fund for Calvert. Both Atlanta and Calvert are units of Eaton Vance."Companies like that can thrive in any environment," he added. "They're not reliant on the capital markets for funding, so they can withstand periods like (the financial crisis of) 2008-09, and they can compound over time."Those traits are reflected in fund performance: strong, not dazzling, with lower downside risk than many of its peers.Calvert Equity outperformed the broad market in the form of the S&P 500 for the past year going into Thursday, up 30.87% vs. 26.95%. Large-cap growth mutual funds tracked by Morningstar Direct averaged 32.56%. And the fund provided shareholders with a smoother ride than its peer group has over time periods stretching from three to 15 years. Over the past three years, for example, the fund has gone down less than 85% of the S&P 500 in downturns, while its peers have averaged declines of more than 110% vs. the big-cap bogey.Calvert analysts sift through a universe of about 2,500 stocks. They pass a pool of 100 to 150 stocks that meet its ESG standards to the fund's Atlanta Capital co-managers. "Then, based on our financial criteria and (low) valuation, we gravitate to the 45 to 50 names that make it into our portfolio," Hudepohl said."Our universe of high quality businesses overlaps a lot with Calvert's universe of businesses that meet their ESG standards," he added.He says companies that satisfy the criteria tend to have tail winds because of those traits. "There are long-term benefits to focusing on clean water like Danaher (DHR), for example, and on clean air like Praxair (PX)."Danaher's products include water treatment and vapor recovery systems. Its earnings per share rose 8%, 10% and 15% the past three quarters. Shares are up 27% in the past 12 months.Praxair makes atmospheric gases, process gases and industrial gas production equipment. EPS grew 7%, 5%, 6% and 8% the past four quarters, which followed eight quarters of EPS declines. Share price rose 37% in the past 12 months. The stock yields 2%.ESG criteria do not prevent the fund from investing in stocks that are popular among investors. FANG stalwarts Facebook (FB), Apple (AAPL) and Google parent Alphabet (GOOG) are holdings.IBD'S TAKE: You can see how Apple's strengths — like its five quarters of earnings per share growth acceleration — stack up against its peers at the stock's easy-to-read IBD Stock Checkup page.Calvert Equity's thesis for Facebook focuses on what Facebook excels at. "Advertising dollars go where the eyeballs are," Hudepohl said. "The internet is taking (consumers) eyeball time away from other media. And Facebook is one of the top truly global platforms after Google (for attracting consumers). It benefits from worldwide growth in attracting advertising dollars."Equity managers like the steady earnings growth prospects for both Mastercard (MA) and Visa (V). "They're two of the better examples of high-quality growth stocks and what we're looking for from a financial perspective," Hudepohl said about the credit card giants.Both companies also appear to have long runways in front of them. "Amazingly, half of all transactions in developed markets are still in cash, so there is a lot of opportunity there," he said. "And within emerging markets like India, China and South America, 90% of transactions are still done in cash."And the two companies avoid taking on consumers' credit risk. "They don't carry loans (from consumers)," Hudepohl said. "They are paid on each swipe of a card because of their technology. And the number of swipes is increasing."Also, the companies have huge free cash flow, Hudepohl says. "So they don't depend on capital markets to grow their businesses," he said. That means they don't have to issue stock or pay interest on loans or bonds to pay for capital expenditures or develop new technology.Charles Schwab (SCHW) benefits from a long-term secular tail wind of online brokers gaining market share, Hudepohl says. Also, Schwab stands to gain from rising interest rates. "(The) low interest rate environment forced Schwab along with the rest of the industry to grant fee waivers on money market funds," Hudepohl said. "As rates rise, those fees are being reinstituted.""Secondly, the low rate environment also compressed net interest margin," he added. "As rates rise, the spread that Schwab earns on its assets should continue to expand. Both benefits carry very high incremental margins to Schwab."RELATED:Here's How Wall Street Professionals Play Bitcoin — Should You?You Need This Much Retirement Savings At Your Age And Income

Graphics-chip maker Nvidia (NVDA) late Thursday bested Wall Street's estimates with stronger-than-expected sales and earnings in its fiscal third quarter.Santa Clara, Calif.-based Nvidia earned $1.33 a share, up 60% year over year, on sales of $2.64 billion, up 32%, in its quarter ended Oct. 29. Analysts expected earnings of 94 cents on sales of $2.36 billion.Nvidia shares seesawed in after-hours trading on the stock market today. They jumped as much as 3%, but then alternated between gains and losses in extended trading.During the regular session Thursday, Nvidia fell 1.8% to 205.32. The stock hit a record high of 212.90 on Tuesday.For the current quarter, Nvidia expects sales to rise 22% year over year to $2.65 billion, topping views. It did not give a target for earnings per share. Wall Street was modeling earnings per share of 97 cents, down 2%, on sales of $2.43 billion, up 12%.IBD'S TAKE: Nvidia is currently ranked No. 6 on the IBD 50 list of top-performing growth stocks.In its fiscal fourth quarter, Nvidia expects to have a gross profit margin of 59.7%, compared with 59.5% in the third quarter."We had a great quarter across all of our growth drivers," Nvidia Chief Executive Jensen Huang said in a news release. "Our Volta GPU (graphics processing unit) has been embraced by every major internet and cloud service provider and computer maker."Huang went on to say: "Our new Tensor inference acceleration platform opens us to growth in hyperscale data centers. GeForce and Nintendo Switch are tapped into the strongest growth dynamics of gaming. And our new Drive PX Pegasus for robo-taxis has been adopted by companies around the world. We are well positioned for continued growth."Nvidia is best known for making graphics processors for PCs and gaming consoles like the Nintendo (NTDOY) Switch, but has a fast-growing business selling GPUs for cloud data centers and artificial intelligence applications.RELATED:Nvidia Looks Overvalued Ahead Of Third-Quarter Earnings: AnalystMicrochip, ON Semi, Skyworks Nab Price-Target Hikes Post-Earnings

Graphics-chip maker Nvidia (NVDA) on Tuesday unveiled a new artificial intelligence computer for fully autonomous vehicles, and announced German logistics giant Deutsche Post DHL Group is deploying a test fleet of self-driving delivery trucks next year using Nvidia technology.XNvidia shares climbed 1.9% to close at 188.93 on the stock market today.Nvidia said its new Drive PX Pegasus platform is engineered for Level 5 autonomous vehicles and can compute more than 10 times faster than its predecessor, the Drive PX 2. The Drive PX Pegasus is already being used by more than 25 companies to develop driverless taxi vehicles, Nvidia said at its GPU Technology Conference in Munich."Creating a fully self-driving car is one of society's most important endeavors — and one of the most challenging to deliver," Nvidia Chief Executive Jensen Huang said in a prepared statement. "The breakthrough AI computing performance and efficiency of Pegasus is crucial for the industry to realize this vision."Driverless cars will enable new ride-sharing and car-sharing services, he said. Plus, automakers will be able to create new types of vehicles that resemble offices or living rooms on wheels, Huang said.IBD'S TAKE: Nvidia stock is listed on IBD's SwingTrader service. SwingTrader applies the rules of IBD's CAN SLIM Investing System in a swing-trading environment to help investors take advantage of short-term trends.Deutsche Post DHL is partnering with Nvidia and auto supplier ZF on its autonomous delivery trucks. It will outfit electric light trucks with the ZF ProAI self-driving system, based on Nvidia Drive PX technology, for automating package transportation and delivery.Deutsche Post DHL currently has a fleet of 3,400 StreetScooter electric delivery vehicles, which can be equipped with ZF's multiple sensors, including cameras, lidar and radar, that feed into the ZF ProAI system.RELATED:Nvidia Gets Price-Target Hike On Artificial Intelligence ViewLooking For The Next Nvidia? Baidu (BIDU) will use Nvidia (NVDA) tech in its cloud-computing platforms and self-driving vehicles. The pact, announced Wednesday, expands an existing partnership between the two tech companies and fuels momentum for autonomous technologies.Autonomous or self-driving technology is too complicated and too important to do it yourself. At least that seems to be the message as automotive companies and technology firms such as General Motors (GM), Alphabet (GOOGL) and Intel (INTC) form self-driving alliances as they try to figure out where they need one another to fill in gaps in expertise.The logic behind Detroit-Silicon Valley pacts is straightforward. Automakers know how to mass produce, distribute and market vehicles, as well as manage tens of thousands of factory workers, whereas tech giants have the edge on electronics, crunching data and rapid innovation.Autonomous and partially autonomous cars will account for 12%-13% of global vehicle sales by 2025, representing a market for those features of roughly $42 billion, the Boston Consulting Group has estimated.Here is a rundown of key "driverless car" alliances:XChipmaker Nvidia (NVDA) and Chinese Internet company Baidu (BIDU) jointly announced Wednesday that they will work together on artificial intelligence (AI) technologies to power cloud data centers, self-driving cars and consumers devices such as home assistants.Notably, the agreement calls for Nvidia's Volta GPUS to be used in Baidu Cloud and its Drive PX supercomputer to be used in Baidu's self-driving car efforts. Baidu simultaneously announced it now has over 50 partners on board its Apollo program, which aims to develop self-driving cars with major Chinese carmakers.Shares of both companies rallied more than 2% on the stock market today.In June, Nvidia announced it is extending self-driving partnerships with European automakers Volkswagen (VLKAY) and Volvo, as well as car-parts maker ZF. The companies will work on advanced artificial intelligence systems for next-generation autonomous technologies.In August 2016, Nvidia and Chinese search giant company Baidu (BIDU) agreed to build a cloud-based computing platform for self-driving cars. It was described as one that would be available for purchase by automakers for their own self-driving vehicles.Apple (AAPL) is leasing six cars from a Hertz (HTZ) subsidiary for testing autonomous software, reports in late June said.While Apple recently confirmed it is working on technology for self-driving cars, it was not clear whether the company will make its own car or just produce the technology for automakers. Reports last year said Apple tried to partner with Daimler and BMW but was rejected.Alphabet and car-rental company Avis Budget (CAR) announced in late June they will work together on self-driving cars. Alphabet's self-driving car unit, Waymo, will rely on Avis to service and store its fleet of Chrysler Pacifica minivans as part of a pilot program in Phoenix, Ariz.In May, Alphabet's Waymo said it would partner with Lyft. Details of the tie-up are sketchy, but it threatens a ride-sharing rival Uber. Waymo is also engaged in a legal spat with Uber.Uber has partnered with German automaker Daimler AG (DDAIF) and Japanese automaker Toyota Motors (TM) for new mobility solutions. It has also reportedly chased self-driving deals with Tesla (TSLA), Fiat Chrysler (FCAU), General Motors (GM), Ford Motor (F) and others.Meanwhile, in January 2017, General Motors invested in Lyft to spur deployment of its cars in autonomous ride-sharing fleets. In February 2017, Ford said it would invest $1 billion in an obscure startup, Argo AI, to build fully self-driving cars. In April 2017, Fiat Chrysler delivered minivans for Waymo-Alphabet's self-driving program.In mid-May, BMW Group, Intel (INTC) and Mobileye (MBLY) announced that they will partner with Delphi Automotive (DLPH) to bring autonomous driving solutions to multiple automakers.Delphi will play a key role in integrating the solution delivered by BMW, Intel and Mobileye into OEM (original equipment manufacturer) vehicle architectures, the companies said in a joint news release. It also may provide components such as sensors and help with customizations to help vehicle brands differentiate themselves.The Delphi partnership is seen as likely to benefit smaller car companies lacking resources to build their own systems.Mobileye, which produces camera-based driver-assistance systems, joined forces in July 2016 with Intel and BMW to make self-driving cars a reality in about five years. In August last year, Delphi and Mobileye teamed up to make turnkey autonomous systems for auto and truck makers.Then in March 2017, Intel decided to acquire Mobileye in a $15 billion deal, capitalizing on the Israeli tech firm's driver-assistance and anti-collision expertise.Delphi said in early May it would focus more aggressively on autonomous driving and would spin off its powertrain unit.In October 2016, Qualcomm (QCOM) agreed to acquire NXP Semiconductors (NXPI), the largest automotive chip supplier, for $47 billion. The mega chip deal is expected create the industry's largest portfolio of sensors, networking and other elements vital to autonomous driving.Elon Musk's Tesla combines auto-manufacturing expertise and technological expertise into one package. The electric carmaker touts its vehicles as having the hardware needed for full self-driving capability, while also testing autonomous technology on the roads, with plans to take it mainstream.Tesla counts Nvidia, whose chips act as the brains of self-driving cars, as a partner. Tesla also partnered with Mobileye, until the two companies broke up over issues tied to Tesla's Autopilot hands-free technology.But chief executive Musk is largely on his own as far as self-driving goals go.RELATED:Tesla Slammed By Goldman Sachs As Sell Rating ReiteratedGoogle's Self-Driving Car Deal Boosts These Rental Car LeadersGoogle's Waymo, Uber Rival Lyft Team Up On Self-Driving CarsDelphi Breaks Out On Earnings, Spinoff In Shift To Self-Driving Future

It took a while for the stock market to shake off March's malaise, but it finally did, with the S&P 500 advancing 1.03% in April, according to Lipper Inc.Reflecting that, U.S. diversified stock mutual funds gained 1.02% as a group last month. Large-cap growth stock mutual funds led the way, notching a 2.65% gain on average.World equity funds did even better in April rising 2.54%. And that helped put them ahead for the past three months with a 7.31% gain.Now several fund managers say they are looking for stocks that should thrive despite the increasing volatility that they expect going forward. Technology, industrials, materials and banks are where they're finding some answers.The broad stock market fell in the first two weeks of April. "Going back to the fourth quarter, there was a lot of enthusiasm for potential policies (that would help stocks) when Trump and a Republican majority in Congress were elected," said Brian Flanagan, lead manager of $1.6 billion Thrivent Mid Cap Stock Fund (AASCX). "Then reality set in when investors saw how hard it might be for some policies to get enacted."Flanagan's fund is an IBD Best Mutual Fund Awards winner for 2017, having outperformed the S&P 500 over the one, three, five and 10 years ended Dec. 31.In addition, early April's market was still weighed down by March's disappointing jobs report and weak retail sales, said David Chalupnik, head of equities for Nuveen Asset Management.The stock market perked up as corporate earnings reports topped expectations, said Bernie Horn, a manager of $418 million Polaris Global Value (PGVFX), another IBD Best Mutual Fund Awards winner by virtue of having topped the MSCI EAFE over the past one, three, five and 10 years.In addition, steady if modest economic growth in Asia and Europe began to hearten investors, Horn said.Global science/technology funds led all sector categories, climbing 3.78% in April.World equity funds gained 2.54% on average, outperforming U.S. diversified stock funds. European region funds rose 4.04%, pacing world equity categories.Taxable bond mutual funds edged ahead 0.75% on average, with Treasury funds up 1.04% and world income funds up 1.11%.Earnings surprises were a key to the late April rally. "In the small-cap space, there were a lot of upward earnings forecast revisions, especially in technology, telecom and materials," said Vincent Costa, co-manager of $322 million Voya Index Plus SmallCap (IPSIX), also an IBD Best Mutual Fund Awards winner.Still, several stock mutual fund managers expect more volatility ahead. "There will be more volatility in the second half of the year," Costa said. "When the Trump agenda gets announced and we have more clarity on what will come down — and what might not — we'll see more volatility. And any disappointments in earnings will fuel volatility."Polaris' Horn says the U.S. economy appears to be ramping up after years of stagnation. "We had eight years of a zombie economy — no real signs of life," he said. "That's changing. We've seen reductions in capacity in areas such as China just as demand has picked up. This is especially helpful to the materials sector."Horn likes BASF (BASFY). "The big German chemical company is starting to see some increases in volumes and pricing, especially in China and Asia," Horn said. "It adds to their ability to generate strong cash flows, which will support higher valuations."Methanex (MEOH) is another materials stock he likes. The Canadian company makes methanol, which is used in the manufacturing of a variety of materials. "They're the largest methanol producer in the world, and they're seeing a lot of increase in demand from China," Horn said.The stock's recent slump reflects the repair closure of a key manufacturing facility in China. "That is not a long-term problem," Horn said.Praxair (PX) is another materials stock favored by Horn. "This is another early-economic cycle company with broad exposure to many industries," Horn said. Earnings per share grew 7% in the first quarter, the first report of positive growth after eight straight quarters of decline. "This shows that underlying industrial production in all parts of the economy is getting better."Like Horn's view on materials, Nuveen's Chalupnik sees an improving outlook for industrials. Industrials sector funds gained 1.99% in April.Chalupnik cites Tennessee-based NN (NNBR), which makes bearing components for the automotive, electrical, agricultural and other industries.Chalupnik oversees the team that runs $1.4 billion Nuveen Small Value (FSCCX), another IBD Best Mutual Fund Awards winner."NN makes precision parts that help cars, for example, improve fuel economy," Chalupnik said. "They've diversified into aerospace, rail, industrial and medical markets. They benefit from U.S. and global growth. Their free cash flow generation is increasing, which they're using to pay down debt."Airlines are an industrials segment that Thrivent's Flanagan likes because they added capacity but have done it to create new segments of low-cost no-frills seats. "These basic economy fares let them compete with ultra-low-cost airlines," he said.He cites Southwest Airlines (LUV). "Many investors were worried about them increasing capacity, but they've done it in a disciplined manner," he said. "Capacity will peak this year. That, combined with a new reservations system, should let them maximize revenue per available seat mile."Voya's Costa remains bullish on banks and outsourcing and consulting within information technology services. In health care, his fund is looking for companies that stand to gain from a rollback or repeal of ObamaCare.Costa and his colleagues expect rising interest rates to further boost banks' net interest margins. Banks accounted for the fund's three biggest holdings as of March 31. Sporting IBD's SMR Rating of A, the banks are Texas Capital Bancshares (TCBI), Sterling Bancorp (STL) and Evercore Partners (EVR). Great Western Bancorp (GWB) was the fund's 10th-largest holding and also has an A SMR Rating.IBD's TAKE: SMR is a proprietary rating pioneered by IBD to help investors identify companies with superior Sales Growth, Profit Margins, and Return on Equity ratios. You can learn more about how to use SMR here at IBD's website.EPlus (PLUS) is one of Costa's smaller holdings. But the provider of IT management products, services and software has a 19% three-year annual earnings growth rate. Shares were up 24% this year through April 30.Flanagan also expects banks, especially regional ones, to continue to benefit from a warming U.S. economy and lighter regulatory burden. Cleveland-based KeyCorp (KEY) is one. It acquired First Niagara Financial Group last year. "Investors are seeing synergy savings that are higher than were expected," Flanagan said. Linde and Praxair (PX) ended talks to create the world's largest supplier of industrial gases, with sources saying that the German company's concerns over jobs and operations at its Munich headquarters the sticking point.The companies had agreed to broad terms and management roles, people with knowledge of the matter said Monday, asking not to be identified as the information is private. They planned to base the holding company for the combined entity in Europe, with the operational center in Praxair's hometown of Danbury, Connecticut, the people said. Linde asked for guarantees to base certain operations and jobs at its Munich headquarters, the people said. Talks between the CEOs broke down over that issue, they said.Linde shares fell 7.7% to 137.50 intraday in Frankfurt, giving it a market value of about $29 billion. Praxair rose fractionally to 117.60 just after the opening bell on stock market today in New York.Linde and Praxair had been in talks since mid-August about a merger that people familiar with the situation at the time said would have been an all-stock deal and may have been valued at more than $30 billion. The tie-up would have been the biggest deal so far in a wave of consolidation triggered by French rival Air Liquide SA's takeover this year of Airgas for $13 billion including debt.IBD'S TAKE: Praxair, with a 2.6% dividend yield, has been a long-time stock winner, though it's lagged the S&P 500 in the past few years. Earnings and sales have declined for several quarters amid tough economic conditions, though sales have been falling at a slower pace and consensus forecasts predicted higher earnings in 2017 through 2020. A rebound off the 200-day moving average might be a potential buy area for income investors.The transaction would have attracted scrutiny from antitrust regulators after Air Liquide, which counts refineries, soda bottlers and welders among its customers, bought Airgas of the U.S. That left only four major suppliers, including Praxair, Linde and Air Products & Chemicals (APD).During the ensuing weeks since August, Linde and Praxair had agreed that Praxair Chief Executive Officer Stephen Angel would run the combined company, with Linde Chairman Wolfgang Reitzle holding the same title and Linde CEO Wolfgang Buechele as president, the people said. The chief financial officer would have come from Praxair.The deal also met opposition from some Linde executives and labor representatives, according to people familiar with the matter. Linde Chief Financial Officer Georg Denoke had some concerns about the deal, according to people familiar with the matter.The discussions were for an almost 50-50 split of ownership in the new company and equal board representation, the people said. The companies aimed for more than $1 billion in annual synergies, they said.The sticking points proved too much to overcome. Preliminary discussions about a combination have ended, according to statements from the companies Monday. While the strategic rationale of a merger "has been principally confirmed," the companies didn't come to an agreement on governance issues, Linde said in a regulatory filing.A spokesman for Linde declined to comment beyond the press release, while a representative for Praxair couldn't be immediately reached for comment outside U.S. business hours."The overlap of businesses was so big that they would've had to divest a lot," Metzler analyst Lars Hettche said by phone. "I was surprised that they pulled out as soon as this though." Talks may have broken down over a "question of power" including the location of the headquarters, he said.In a historical twist, the tie-up would have reunited the U.S. industrial gas business with the German company it created more than a century ago. Praxair was started in 1907 by Carl von Linde, a pioneer in refrigeration who helped found the company that bears his name. The firm emerged from the Union Carbide group as an independent business in 1992.Linde CEO Buechele has been cutting costs after a move into supplying gases to treat chronic illnesses such as asthma failed to offset slowing demand among industrial customers. Joining with Praxair may have helped overcome investors' concerns about Linde in an industry where returns are steady yet growth is limited.Now, management will be under pressure to convince shareholders of Linde's stand-alone prospects, especially as its annual profit margin of about 12.27% lags behind Praxair's 22.82% profitability, according to Bloomberg data. That could lead Buechele to be more rigorous on reducing costs, according to Andreas Heine of MainFirst Bank."We were not convinced that the merger would be beneficial for Linde shareholders," DZ Bank analyst Peter Spengler wrote in a note Monday. "There is no need for a merger at this large scale in our view."RELATED:Potash Corp., Agrium To Merge, Creating Fertilizer Giant

Tesla Motors (TSLA) partner Nvidia (NVDA) is making a grab for NXP Semiconductors' (NXPI) piece of the autonomous-driving market, Needham analyst Rajvindra Gill said Wednesday after Nvidia unveiled the guts of its self-driving engine.On Monday, Nvidia revealed its Parker mobile processor, which the company said is 50%-100% more powerful than other mobile processors. Two Parker chips and two Pascal graphics processing units (GPUs) run the Drive PX 2 system for self-driving.Nvidia beat NXP to the market with its Drive PX 2 platform launch in January. But NXP has the largest share of any single player on the market, at 14.2%, according to market research firm Strategy Analytics, Gill wrote in a research report Wednesday.Infineon, Renesas (potentially attempting to acquire automotive-chip firm Intersil (ISIL)), STMicroelectronics (STM), Texas Instruments (TXN), Robert Bosch, ON Semiconductor (ON), Micron Technology (MU) and Toshiba each have 10% or less of the market, he said.The remaining 39% of the $27.4 billion global advanced driver assistance system (ADAS) market is made up of players with less than 1%. That's likely where Nvidia lands. But Nvidia won't stay there for long, Gill predicts."Capitalizing on the trend toward connective self-driving cars, Nvidia is well positioned to gain not only market share, but also increase its (average sales prices) as autonomous applications should command a higher premium than infotainment computing," he wrote.IBD'S TAKE: Mobileye, too, is shoring up its autonomous-driving offerings by partnering with Delphi, the company said Tuesday. The duo plans to release a Level 4/5 automated driving system to integrate into vehicles in 2019.Parker chips are scalable and can be used to host infotainment, digital instrument clusters and ADAS platforms. Drive PX 2 synthesizes information from sensors, vehicle-to-vehicle information, high-definition mapping and algorithmic processing.Together, that's enough for Level 5 automation, which can run a vehicle without any human intervention. The market is largely focused on Level 2 and 3 automation, which can handle adaptive cruise control and parking assistance, among other functions.But tech giants like Apple (AAPL) and Alphabet's (GOOGL) Google have big dreams for full automation. During the recent Intel (INTC) Developer Forum in San Francisco, the No. 1 chipmaker delved deeper into its partnership with BMW (BMWYY) and Mobileye (MBLY) for autonomous driving.In early afternoon trading on the stock market today, Nvidia stock was down a fraction, above 62.50, but its shares have soared more than 75% the past three months, and it's an IBD 50 stock.

But the segment is bound to see some unfettered competition, MKM analyst Ian Ing wrote in a report."We note headlines on an autonomous driving partnership between BMW (BMWYY), Mobileye (MBLY) and Intel (INTC); Intel acquiring Nervana and Apple (AAPL) acquiring Turi for deep learning," he wrote.Alphabet (GOOGL) and NXP Semiconductors (NXPI) are also working in autonomous driving.But main GPU rival Advanced Micro Devices (AMD) is "more constrained and resource-challenged," Ing said.He maintained his buy rating and 70 price target on Nvidia stock.

It's April and Nvidia (NVDA) CEO Jen-Hsun Huang is relying on "Star Wars" droids R2D2, C3PO and BB8 -- or brightly-colored vehicular versions of them -- to demonstrate his point at Nvidia's GPU Technology Conference in San Jose, Calif. Autonomous driving isn't a "Jetsons" trope. It's here.Using Nvidia's Drive PX platform for self-driving cars, BB8 learned over 72 hours and 3,000 miles how to navigate dirt roads, circumvent traffic jams and avoid pedestrians. And BB8 did it all using a graphics-chip-powered supercomputer.This isn't your daddy's GPU.Traditionally, graphics processing units are mostly installed in desktop and laptop computers to handle heavyweight image rendering for gaming, including games used with Facebook's (FB) virtual-reality headset Oculus Rift. But Nvidia isn't about to stop there, says Danny Shapiro, the company's automotive marketing director."We've taken our GPUs for non-graphics operations: hyperscale computing, scientific discovery, molecular modeling, drug discovery, cancer research," Shapiro told IBD. "Any kind of high-performance computing needs, people are turning to our GPUs to do that. We're filling data centers."Nvidia counts Amazon.com (AMZN), Facebook, IBM (IBM), Microsoft (MSFT) and Twitter (TWTR) among its customers. Its chips, says Huang, already have achieved "superhuman" levels of artificial intelligence. The company also partners with Tesla Motors (TSLA) vs. Apple (AAPL), Alphabet (GOOGL) and Ford (F) in the nascent self-driving-car battle.Investors like the road ahead: Nvidia stock touched a record high above 48 on June 20, and it's been in the IBD 50 ranking of top-performing stocks.The GPU opportunity in autonomous vehicles?"It's going to be huge," Shapiro said in an interview. "The reality is, it's really transformative."In 2019, Baird analyst Tristan Gerra estimates the automotive semiconductor market will reach $28 billion, at a 6% compound annual growth rate, on sensor and radar chips alone. That doesn't include GPU sales -- and while Nvidia doesn't make sensors or radar chips, that gives a clue about the potential size of this market.MKM analyst Ian Ing agrees that the GPU car market will be massive. And Nvidia really is the pole-sitter here.Top GPU rival Advanced Micro Devices (AMD) -- which declined to comment during its quiet period ahead of its Q2 earnings release on July 21 -- is largely entrenched only in the gaming sector, Ing told IBD. And Intel's (INTC) GPUs are often panned as inferior for desktop gaming, though the No. 1 overall chipmaker also focuses on smartphone and tablet GPUs.The competition among tech and car companies to develop a truly autonomous, mass-marketed vehicle continues to heat up. Apple, Alphabet, Tesla and Ford are among the companies striving for the secret sauce. Regardless of who wins, machine learning is a necessity for autonomous driving, Ing says."The Google Cars in Mountain View (Calif.), if you program them to exactly follow the rules of the road, they actually cannot drive effectively because they're dealing with all the human drivers," Ing said. "Human drivers won't let them merge into traffic ... or give proper distance."They need to adjust and adapt, and effectively learn how to get from Point A to Point B."And that's the goal of Nvidia's autonomous-driving platform, coined as "Drive PX 2." It's powered by two systems-on-a-chip (comprised of a GPU and a central processing unit) and two additional bleeding-edge GPUs. That system is the power equivalent of 150 Apple MacBook Pros, says Sean Wix, Nvidia technical market manager.Drive PX 2 runs data compiled by 12 cameras as well as lidar, radar and ultrasonic sensors through what the company calls DaveNet. That's Nvidia's deep neutral network software for autonomous driving. The software has been integrated into the Drive PX 2 platform and trained to operate a car.Nvidia's Shapiro says PX 2, launched in January, outperforms PX 1 by a factor of 10.Shapiro likened DaveNet's training to that of a child. DaveNet builds its "vocabulary" through pictures. But pictures, to a computer, are just pixels until logic is applied. The traditional system of computer programming via a series of "if" and "then" options isn't optimal for driving, he says, because there is just too much randomness in driving."Deep-learning lets us train the vehicle how to interpret and pick the right action based on teaching it the experiential data," he told IBD. And unlike human drivers, "our cars aren't going to speed, they're not going to text, they're not going to be drunk."That should cut way down on wrecks, Shapiro says. He estimates 90%, or more, are caused by human error.Nvidia has some competition in the form of field-programmable gate arrays (FPGAs) by Xilinx (XLNX) and Intel (via its Altera acquisition), but MKM's Ing doesn't see the "smaller design community" gaining much traction vs. GPUs. Unlike GPUs, which use software to learn, FPGAs are a hardware solution.Still, Xilinx has shipped 100 million devices to automotive and transportation customers, says Baird's Gerra. Xilinx's FPGAs support real-time analytics, video processing and displays, data transport and integration for advanced driver assistance systems.Nvidia supplies GPUs for six of the so-called Super 7 cloud service players -- Facebook, Google, Microsoft, Amazon, Baidu (BIDU) and Alibaba (BABA) (but not Tencent (TCEHY)). That's a major boon, says MKM's Ing, but it's difficult to completely size the market opportunity."These deep-learning boxes (for data centers that power cloud systems), you're talking about tens of thousands of dollars of content per box and eight or nine high-performing GPU cards at a couple thousand dollars each, maybe $20,000 to $30,000 per box," he said.Initially, Nvidia's artificial intelligence opportunity is in the cloud, Ing says. Beyond that, he expects virtual reality to take a strong foothold in 2017, with autonomous driving following in 2018. Baird's Gerra has a 2018-2022 target for efficient self-driving vehicles.Gaming is really the market where AMD competes with Nvidia, Ing says. AMD's GPU prices have held up better during the recent gaming refresh than Nvidia's, he said in a June 7 research report. Nvidia customers are experiencing shortages after the company's Pascal architecture launch on May 27.Still, gaming remains Nvidia's bread-and-butter segment and will continue to be so amid the artificial intelligence and autonomous driving race, Shapiro told IBD. In Q1, gaming represented more than half of Nvidia's total sales, with data center and automotive at 11% apiece.Although data center and automotive sales accelerated 47% and 62.5%, respectively, vs. the year-earlier quarter, Shapiro sees gaming remaining key for Nvidia.Unlike PCs, gaming is growing, and the VR opportunity is colossal."Gaming is still a big part of our company, and it still continues to grow despite the fact the PC industry is shrinking, and despite the fact other companies are laying off people in droves," Shapiro said. "Our gaming group is growing."Nvidia shares fell 5.7% on the stock market today after hitting a record high on Thursday. Apple closed down 2.8%. Alphabet lost 4.15%, setting an 8-month closing low.

Tesla Motors (TSLA) partner Nvidia (NVDA) developed a supercomputer capable of performing 24 trillion operations per second -- that's more powerful than 150 Apple (AAPL) Macbook Pros -- and it will run autopilot-capable vehicles in 12-18 months, Nvidia told IBD on Thursday.Nvidia imagines a $6 billion to $10 billion automotive opportunity, RBC Capital analyst Mitch Steves said Thursday in a research note. Of that, $2 billion will be in the digital cockpit, $2 billion in self-driving cars and $2 billion to $6 billion on transportation-as-a-service.Steves boosted his price target on Nvidia stock to 47 from 40.Canaccord analyst Matthew Ramsay, too, upped his price target on Nvidia stock, to 55 from 45, noting that the company's four target growth areas -- gaming, enterprise, data center and automotive -- now comprise 90% of non-royalty revenue."We maintain our belief Nvidia's transformation from a PC-leveraged GPU (graphics processing unit) supplier to a diverse visual-computing company is now complete," Ramsay wrote in his research note Thursday. He sees Nvidia hitting $3.50 earnings per share ex items in fiscal 2021, even as it battles Apple and Alphabet (GOOGL) for the nascent self-driving car market.Despite those bullish views, Nvidia stock closed down 1.75% at 46.72 on the stock market today. Shares are up about 44% for the year, though, after Nvidia launched its new gaming architecture, Pascal, and its second-generation self-driving platform.Nvidia launched its Drive PX 2 platform for autonomous driving in January, and it outperforms its first-generation cousin by a factor of 10, Danny Shapiro, Nvidia's senior director of automotive, told IBD in a recent interview. Four months later, NXP Semiconductors (NXPI) launched its rival platform, BlueBox.BlueBox can deliver 90,000 DMIPS (million instructions per second). Explains Shapiro: "That's like 90 giga instructions per second. We're at 24 tera instructions per second, or 24,000 giga instructions per second."Most of Nvidia's automotive sales stem from Drive CX, its digital cockpit and infotainment system, Steves wrote. In the long term, Nvidia expects Drive PX 2 to displace CX as its top seller. And Nvidia is still investing in fully autonomous vehicles.In virtual reality, Nvidia forecasts a 3 million unit opportunity expanding at a 52% compound annual growth rate to 16 million units by 2020, Steves wrote. Nvidia's GPUs are suggested for use with Facebook's (FB) Oculus Rift VR system.Only about 20% of Nvidia's GeForce installed base, 80 million units, has updated to VR-capable GPUs, Ramsay wrote in his report. And GeForce, Nvidia's gaming GPUs, has only penetrated about 10% of the emerging market.As such, "we believe the Nvidia gaming franchise is well positioned for sustained strong low-teens growth, catalyzed by the launch of Pascal," Ramsay wrote.But rival Advanced Micro Devices (AMD) will scoop 30% of Nvidia's discrete GPU market over the next several years on its Polaris launch, Ramsay wrote. Discrete GPUs don't have an integrated central processing unit. Nvidia will continue to hold the premium PC market, he predicts.

Tesla Motors (TSLA) partner Nvidia (NVDA) expects Apple (AAPL) and Alphabet (GOOGL) to eat its autonomous-car dust, as Audi and other carmakers parlay Nvidia's GPU-powered platform into consumer vehicles within a year, Wedbush analyst Betsy Van Hees said Wednesday.Nvidia launched its Drive PX 2 platform for autonomous driving in January and sees consumers buying vehicles installed with the system within the next 12 months. The company is aiming for complete vehicular autonomy by 2020.Unlike Nvidia's GPU-run Drive PX 2, NXP's system uses a central computing engine. MKM analyst Ian Ing says GPUs -- traditionally used to quickly render PC images for gaming -- are better positioned to tackle "homogeneous and repetitive computing."Nvidia says its platform uses ultrasonic sensors to produce a 360-degree visual. The company expects incremental adoption over the next five years. Van Hees notes Audi's A8 model next year will use Nvidia products.At the closing bell on the stock market today, Nvidia stock was up 1%, to 47.36. Shares have jumped 42% the past six months vs. 5% growth in IBD's 41-company Electronic Semiconductor-Fabless industry group as a whole.

Nvidia (NVDA) received a downgrade Monday from an analyst who is bullish about the chipmaker's technology but concerned about the expiration of a six-year licensing deal with Intel. Chip stocks rose Thursday as semiconductor companies unveiled products for connected cars, wearable devices and the Internet of Things (IoT) at this week's Consumer Electronics Show in Las Vegas.
In a keynote address Tuesday, Intel (INTC) CEO Brian Krzanich made several product announcements, including a collaboration with sports eyewear maker Oakley for wearables.

Intel unveiled a button-size prototype module for wearables that it calls "Curie," a system on a chip based on a Quark SE processor with a Bluetooth low energy radio, sensors and rechargeable battery. The module is slated to ship in the second half of the year.

Krzanich also highlighted "Nixie," the 2014 "Make it Wearable" challenge winner that Intel says is the first wearable camera that can fly. Nixie can be fastened to the wrist like a bracelet, then unfolds and takes flight on cue to take photos.
Intel stock was near 37, up more than 2% in afternoon trading in the stock market today.

Chip supplier NXP Semiconductors (NXPI), based in Eindhoven, Netherlands, unveiled a smart-car access chip that combines keyless entry and a radio-frequency transmitter for remote control. The chip, dubbed NCF29A1, creates car-access solutions that can be embedded in smartphones, smartwatches, car keys and other devices, NXP said.
NXP also announced that it's expanding its investment in Cohda Wireless, a software company specializing in car-safety applications.

Torsten Lehmann, NXP senior vice president of car infotainment and driver assistance, said in a company press release that the investment marks another step "in our quest to make the secure connected car a reality and to improve road safety and traffic flow." NXP's chips enable cars to communicate with one another and with surrounding traffic infrastructure by wirelessly exchanging warning messages and traffic information, the statement said.
NXP stock was up 4% in afternoon trading Thursday, near 77.

Santa Clara, Calif.-based Marvell Technology Group (MRVL) introduced a suite of "Smart Life and Smart Lifestyle" chips and Kinoma software platforms for the IoT, digital entertainment, cars, 3D printers, smartphones and tablets, and other devices. Marvell stock was up more than 6% in afternoon trading, near 16.

Nvidia (NVDA) touted its Tegra X1 mobile processor for future cars, claiming that the processor can carry out more than a trillion operations per second while drawing limited electrical power. Nvidia also unveiled two specialized automotive computers, powered by the new chip, that it says can enable cars to see their surroundings, provide warnings to drivers and, eventually, drive themselves.
Nvidia stock was up nearly 4% in afternoon trading, near 20.

The Tegra X1 has eight standard processors based on designs licensed by ARM Holdings (ARMH), Nvidia said in a statement. Nvidia will unveil the Tegra X1 in the first half of this year. ARM Holdings stock was up 1.7% in afternoon trading, near 45.

Drive PX, one of the Nvidia car computers that uses the chip, is designed as a platform for developing autopilot capabilities. Nvidia says that Drive PX can process video from up to 12 high-definition cameras to help create a 360-degree view around the car.
The IBD Electronics-Semiconductor Manufacturing group, which includes Intel, was up 3% Thursday afternoon.
The Electronics-Semiconductors Fabless group, which includes NXP, Marvell, Nvidia and ARM, was up nearly 2%.

Fuel cell maker Plug Power (PLUG) is on a roll. Its stock rose for the seventh time in eight trading sessions early Thursday after Newark Farmers Market, a customer since 2011, said it will expand its investment in hydrogen fuel cell technology. It was Plug Power's second new contract announcement in as many days. Newark Farmers Market said it will…

Fuel-cell maker Plug Power (PLUG) signed a long-term distribution agreement with Praxair (PX), which will increase availability of hydrogen for a growing number of fuel-cell powered vehicles and other devices.

In a separate deal, FuelCell Energy (FCEL), which sells large fuel-cell power systems to utilities and others, inked a deal with its South Korean partner Posco Energy for six fuel-cell modules totaling 8.4 megawatts of energy.
No financial terms were disclosed for either agreement.

Fuel cells use a chemical reaction to combine hydrogen and oxygen, which in the process releases energy that is captured for use in forklifts, autos, power plants and other items. It's among the cleanest technologies because virtually the only byproduct is water.
But because it's a nascent industry, costs are still relatively high. The contracts may help move the industry toward a more cost-competitive basis.
Plug Power shares shot up as much as 7% early Tuesday before settling to a 4% gain in morning trading in the stock market today. Praxair was down fractionally.

Fuel-cell stocks are not highly rated because of volatility in the young industry. Winning stocks are of companies with high earnings and revenue growth. Fuel-cell companies are growing but generally don't have a winning track record yet.

Plug Power and Praxair said in a joint press statement the agreement, "pairs Plug Power's GenFuel hydrogen fueling infrastructure solution with Praxair's liquid hydrogen supply capability, helping customers realize productivity and environmental benefits."
Natural gases giant Praxair recently announced it was expanding capacity and, when completed in 2015, Praxair's new Niagara Falls liquid hydrogen production capacity will increase by 50%.

Meanwhile, FuelCell inked a deal to ship additional fuel-cell modules to Posco, which operates the world's largest fuel-cell power plant. With the addition, Posco has now purchased 17.7 megawatts of fuel-cell modules, along with 42 MW of fuel-cell kits under an existing multiyear 122 MW order.

South Korea is an early fuel-cell adopter. Today, 18 fuel cell parks are operating in 13 cities there, generating more than 140 MW of power for the electric grid, including a Posco-owned plant that generates 59 MW of power.
FuelCell's stock price was down about 2% early Tuesday.

It didn't take long for a major buyout to have a positive impact on Minerals Technologies' financial results — or for Wall Street to take note of the specialty mineral producer's blowout third quarter.Minerals Technologies (MTX) shares rose 20% over a six-session period beginning on Sept. 24 — setting new closing highs each session and ending at a closing peak of 76.71 on Oct. 31 — after the company sprinted past Q3 earnings views and saw its revenue more than double from the prior year.A big driver of the gains was its May buyout of Amcol International, an Illinois-based producer of bentonite clay.That $1.7 billion deal came after Minerals Technologies won a bidding war for Amcol against Imerys, a French industrial materials firm. The addition of Amcol fattened the top line and widened the company's footprint into new geographies and product categories.Paper ChaseThe business of MTI — short for Minerals Technologies Inc. — includes five segments: Specialty Minerals, Refractories, Performance Materials, Construction Technologies and Energy Services.It is probably best known as the world's largest producer of precipitated calcium carbonates (PCC) used in the manufacture of paper. The PCC business accounted for 47% of MTI's revenue in 2013.The Amcol acquisition expanded MTI's business on a couple of fronts, CEO Joseph Muscari told IBD: "It gives us more diversification in minerals, so we are staying close to what we know. It also helps us from a geographic expansion standpoint. We're able to do more in terms of leveraging the resources we have in India, China, Thailand, Indonesia and South America."The addition of Amcol helped MTI deliver what Muscari called its "highest quarter ever." MTI dates back to 1992, when it was spun off from Pfizer (PFE).On Oct. 23, MTI logged Q3 earnings of $1.25 a share, up from 63 cents the prior year and well above consensus estimates. Sales more than doubled to $543.5 million.In a research note, JPMorgan analyst Jeffrey Zekauskas said MTI's operating income of $76.8 million exceeded his own forecast of $69.8 million, reflecting a "better-than-expected operating performance and cost synergies in the acquired Amcol divisions."MTI is about nine months ahead of schedule in terms of cost savings from the Amcol buyout, Zekauskas noted. Much of the work ahead will be focused on improving Amcol's operations. "We believe there is a large runway for (MTI) to improve business processes across the company," he said. "The Amcol plants run at very low levels of capacity utilization, and overhead costs are relatively high."CEO Muscari said the sharp rise in MTI's stock price following its Q3 earnings release was partly due to the way it has handled the Amcol acquisition: "We hadn't done an acquisition of this size before, so investors could see we were able to do it very well — that synergies were falling to the bottom line. Over the next two to three years we are going to be very focused on integrating Amcol and capturing all the synergies."MTI also eyes big things from Amcol's main product. Bentonite boasts a diverse number of end uses that range from cat litter to construction products and bondings for metal castings.The latter category shows particular promise, Muscari said, particularly in China: "China is the largest casting producing market in the world, and (Amcol) has a good market share there. As the China market continues to grow, we will grow with it."More than half of MTI's 2013 revenue came from the U.S., while 27% came from Europe and Africa. Although Asia markets contributed only 11% of the total, that figure is likely to move much higher in coming years as MTI looks to grow its presence in the region."China and India are at the top of the list in terms of geographic expansion, along with Southeast Asia and Brazil," Muscari said. "We have been in China since the '90s, so we have very well established management there. In India, we didn't even have a position at all in paper PCC four years ago. Today we have a relatively high market share for paper makers there."R&D EffortsOne way MTI boosts its market share is through product development, particularly in its PCC business. The company's research and development efforts focus on helping customers save money, produce higher quality products and reduce pollution.Muscari points to MTI's Fulfill brand of high-filler technologies. These are designed to let manufacturers put more filler in their paper and less pulp, which saves money.While new products and markets will help MTI expand its top line, the company's bottom line should get a boost from a restructuring program that mainly involves reducing its workforce.According to MTI's Q3 earnings release, the restructuring will occur across all business segments and is estimated to provide annualized savings of $20 million.Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters expect MTI to report full-year 2014 earnings of $3.80 a share, up 57% from the prior year. They see 2015 EPS rising 19% to $4.51.Mineral Technologies belongs to IBD's Chemicals-Specialty group. The largest stocks in the group by market cap are Praxair (PX), Air Products & Chemicals (APD) and Sigma-Aldrich (SIAL).

On a full-year1 basis, earnings growth for the S&P 500 is expected to remain solid. Double-digit gains are expected on both a median firm and total net income basis. On a median basis, growth for the current and next fiscal year is expected to be 13.7% and 12.8%, respectively. This growth rate has stayed relatively stable (slight downward drift for 2007) over the last several weeks. On a total earnings basis, the growth rates are more skewed towards this year, at 15.4% versus 9.7% next year. While the total growth rate is certainly predicted to slow, by no means is a 9.7% year-over-year growth rate tantamount to predicting a near term recession. Further, with the revisions ratios of both 2006 and 2007 above 1.0, a significant deterioration of the expected growth rate does not look likely at this point.

We would point to a couple of technical points which are affecting the expected growth rates. The rates are based on the forecasts of EPS, and then multiplied by current shares outstanding to get total earnings. Recently firms have been pumping enormous, and unprecedented, sums into share repurchase. In the first half, over $216 billion was spent by S&P 500 firms to buy back their own stock. The shrinks the number of shares outstanding and boosts the EPS growth rate. Add in dividends paid out and over 80% of earnings were returned to shareholders rather than reinvested by the companies. Countering this is the expensing of options this year. As recently as last year companies were allowed to use bogus intrinsic value accounting for stock options. In other words pretend that there was no cost to the company for making its executives extraordinarily rich in many cases. Now they have to realize that compensation is indeed an expense, which holds down reported earnings growth, even if there is no change in the economic earnings. Unlike some other earnings databases, our estimates fully include the effect of expensing options (which would explain why our numbers are somewhat lower than theirs).

On a full-year1  basis, earnings growth for the S&P 500 is expected to remain solid. Double-digit gains are expected on both a median firm and total net income basis. On a median basis, growth for the current and next fiscal year is expected to be 13.6% and 12.1%, respectively. This growth rate has stayed relatively stable (slight downward drift for 2007) over the last several weeks. On a total earnings basis, the growth rates are more skewed towards this year, at 15.3% versus 9.7% next year. While the total growth rate is certainly predicted to slow, by no means is a 9.7% year-over-year growth rate tantamount to predicting a near term recession. Further, with the revisions ratios of both 2006 and 2007 above 1.0, a significant deterioration of the expected growth rate does not look likely at this point.

We would point to a couple of technical points which are affecting the expected growth rates. The rates are based on the forecasts of EPS, and then multiplied by current shares outstanding to get total earnings. Recently firms have been pumping enormous, and unprecedented, sums into share repurchase. In the first half, over $216 billion was spent by S&P 500 firms to buy back their own stock. The shrinks the number of shares outstanding and boosts the EPS growth rate. Add in dividends paid out and over 80% of earnings were returned to shareholders rather than reinvested by the companies. Countering this is the expensing of options this year. As recently as last year, companies were allowed to use bogus intrinsic value accounting for stock options. In other words pretend that there was no cost to the company for making its executives extraordinarily rich in many cases. Now they have to realize that compensation is indeed an expense, which holds down reported earnings growth, even if there is no change in the economic earnings. Unlike some other earnings databases, our estimates fully include the effect of expensing options (which would explain why our numbers are somewhat lower than theirs).

When making investment decisions, growth should always be looked at in conjunction with how much you are paying for a stock. Thus, it makes sense to look at the total earnings expected for a sector, relative to that sectors total market capitalization. This is basically a variation on looking at the P/E.

The chart below shows the share of total earnings for 2005, 2006 and 2007, as well as the share of total market capitalization for each sector (the final bar shown). Since the S&P 500 is a market cap weighted index, this is the same as its index weight. On the chart below, the difference between the sizes of the first three bars shows if a sector is gaining or losing earnings share. The difference between the final bar and the first three bars shows if the sector is selling for an above or below market P/E. If the final bar is smaller than the other bars, the sector is selling for a below market P/E. However, as opposed to just showing the sector P/Es, it also shows the relative importance of the sectors to the overall index.

Clearly the Financials are the biggest influence on the market, with a weight of 21.4%, it has more influence than the Consumer Staples, Utilities, Materials and Telecom sectors combined. However, that sector is also relatively cheap on an earnings basis, and thus serves to hold the overall P/E of the index down. In other words, Financials deserve to be the biggest influence on the market, since they contribute 26.4% of the total expected earnings for 2006, or more than the total earnings of the Tech, Industrial and Utility sectors combined.

Energy looks to be under represented in its influence on the market since it is expected to provide 14.5% of total earnings for 2006, but represents only 9.7% of the total market capitalization of the index. While its earnings share is currently expected to decline to 13.8% in 2007, even on this basis it is still much cheaper than the overall market. Clearly at 9.7%, Energy is far from being in a bubble phase. Frankly, I find the notion of an Energy stock bubble to be absurd. Even though the NASDAQ is at only half of its early 2000 peak, a much stronger case could be made for Tech being bubbly than for Energy.

Looked at another way, Energy will provide 20.6% of the total incremental earnings in the S&P 500 this year, while that is down from the 38.7% of the total it provided last year, it is still far above its weight in the index. In more conventional terms, the Energy sector is trading for 10.5x 2006, and 10.1x 2007 earnings. Tech on the other hand is trading for 22.4x 2006 and 19.2x 2007 earnings.
